text: Patient: And she started taking this fluorescence. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Are you familiar with that? Doctor: Uh-uh. What does that do? Family Member: Purifies the toxins inside your body. Patient: Detoxes, detoxification. Doctor: Okay. Alright. Family Member: Is that good for him to be taking? Doctor: Yeah. No. You’re on a medicine that interacts with everything known to mankind. XTANDI is, remember we talked about how it’s processed through the liver? So it’d be good if you don’t add on extra stuff that will tax your liver that would make the XTANDI either work less or more. More is not necessarily better, and it might make you have more side effects. Family Member: Have you heard of fluorescence? Doctor: Never heard of it. But in general we try to stay away from too many supplements on drugs like XTANDI because it is a known interactor Family Member: Oh. Oh. It’s not a drug. It’s like a homeopathic. Doctor: of many existing drugs. You have to be careful. Right. But all of those are drugs. They really are.

text: Family Member 1: Yes, super hormones uh for what duration? Doctor: We, uh I give them for three months for four doses of chemo three weeks apart. Family Member 1: And let me ask you um, Are there any treatments that you use with the PSMA that targeted those cells, um? Doctor: Um yes, so, so, you’re talking about like PSMA radionuclide therapy and um right now there are a couple of clinical trials in the United States for guys who have failed hormone therapy. There are also – um you can do that – I’ve sent probably; uh I’ve sent twelve guys over to Germany to get that therapy in the last eighteen months uh you know specifically to try and like avoid like hormone therapy or something. What I can tell you is in this setting that therapy is not curing anybody. So if you’d asked me eighteen months ago, I would have said sure, let’s send you over there. What I’ve learned in the last eighteen months is that nobody I’ve sent over has been cured by that therapy, and uh I don’t consider it worthwhile right now. Family Member 1: Okay, and then the other question was - I don’t know if this makes a difference or not, Do we have a Gleason score of the margins that were left? Doctor: So it’s and uh irrelevant and undoable because you know the therapy he received, uh we wouldn’t uh it’s not scored. Family Member 1: I see. Doctor: So it’s, But it’s irrelevant. The cancer’s out. It’s an aggressive cancer. Family Member 1: Um Hmm. Patient: What are the side effects from the chemo and super hormones? Doctor: Yeah, uh so the biggest side effect, quite frankly, so let’s talk about hormones first. Uh because the super hormones don’t add anything. Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: Yeah, I’ll just stick with the prednisone. Doctor: Okay. And you can definitely try cutting back on the dose okay because as you saw in the scans, remember last time I had given you a slight inkling that it was heading starting to grow back? Patient: Yes. Doctor: And when we did the recent scans are showing a continued slight increase. So it’s a small increase, the bone scan is still completely okay and so you do not have the spread to the bone that we can see. Patient: Yeah, right, right. Doctor: Uh because of that I think we should stop this treatment. Okay because you’ve sort of gotten the benefit you’re going to get out of it and it may be time to move on to other treatment. Now in terms of other treatments what to go to next? And uh there is a medication that is something called Niraparib okay. And it’s sort of this family of medications called barhabiters. And the way they work is if your cancer expresses certain specific mutations, they it’s likely to be effective. So if you treat everybody with your kind of prostate cancer on this medication, the chances of it working were wherever fifty to twenty percent, so pretty low. When we looked at just the people with those mutations that were expressed in the cancer, then the response went up to seventy eighty percent. So what we’re doing… Family Member: For prostate? Doctor: So what we’re doing – yes, yeah, within prostate cancer. So what we’re doing now is what we’re proposing is that we screen your uh blood, it’s a blood test, that to look for any of those eight genes or mutations that if your cancer has those then I would recommend going on this particular study which gives you these medications which are pills that you would take and we’d monitor you to see if it’s likely to be helpful. Family Member: Is it a type of chemo? Doctor: It is not. It is something called parp… so more like what we call targeted therapy. Okay but it’s different from the immune therapy that you were having. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And I think it has a pretty good shot at working like I said if you had one of those mutations.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Like next Tuesday or next Wednesday. But I think either way, because of this anemia that has come back, uh, the trial at the very least will require us to stop the medication until the hemoglobin increases. Patient: Hum. Family Member: So are there other things that he can do like, say, for instance, you know, maybe take an iron or, but are there food products that he can eat that might help with increasing, uh, his blood? Doctor: Well, there’s many, you know, causes for anemia. And the only one of them that is helped by iron is iron-deficiency anemia. Iron-deficiency anemia is typically, one, caused by bleeding from somewhere. Family Member: Hum. Doctor: So, uh, I really don’t think you have the iron-deficiency anemia, and so, uh, I don’t think that will help that much, unfortunately. You know? I wouldn’t discourage you from taking iron if you want to. Patient: Um hum. Okay. Doctor: Or if you want to eat iron-rich foods, uh, like- Family Member: But you’re thinking this is basically because of the medication? The study medication? Doctor: Yeah. I’m pretty sure. I’m pretty sure because, I mean, he actually had some degree of mild anemia before he went on the study. Part of that could have been from the cancer of the bone or marrow, specifically, but clearly when he went on the drug, it got worse, and it dropped back one to two points. So, uh, but you might need a transfusion, however. But that’s a possibility. Patient: Um hum. Okay. Doctor: So as of today, you know, stopping the . Okay? Uh, let’s plan to do, uh, forgot what the lab was. Is it K___?

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
